Project Description: The Project addresses the problems of loss of forest cover and
conversion  of  state  forestlands  by  instituting  participatory
sustainable  forest  management  through  improving  livelihood
opportunities,  reducing  poverty,  and  improving  forest  sector
governance. The Project, consistent with the sector approach
and  the 1995 Forestry Sector Master Plan (FSMP), comprises
(i) policy and institutional  reforms to make local communities

development  and  management,  (ii)  technical  and  operational
capacity  building  of  the  Executing  Agency  (the  Ministry  of
Forestry  and  Environment  [MFE])  and  the  participating
communities to improve their effectiveness, and (iii) investments
for increasing forest resource production from public and private
lands.

Rationale: Increasing  forest  loss  and  degradation,  and  accompanied
impoverishment of the  communities whose livelihoods depend
on forests are dual challenges faced by Sri Lanka. Poverty and
food insecurity is increasing especially among people living near
traditional forest areas or plantations. Consequently, they are
increasingly  encroaching  on  the  forest,  resulting  in  forest
conversion and degradation.  In the long run, impoverishment
and    land  degradation  lead  to  food  deficits  that  necessitate
further   extension   of   agriculture  to  the  adjacent   forestlands,

I.  THE PROPOSAL
1. I submit for your approval the following Report and Recommendation on a proposed
loan to the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka for the Forest Resources Management
Sector Project.
II.  INTRODUCTION
2. The Government of Sri Lanka sought assistance from the Asian Development Bank
(ADB) in 1997 to finance a project aimed at promoting sustainable forest resource management.
The preparation of the Project was carried out under ADB technical assistance (TA).1 Following
completion of the TA, fact-finding was carried out in 1999 and ADB appraised the Project from
8-23 March 2000.2 This report has been based on the feasibility  study  and  the  mission’s
discussions with the representatives of Government agencies, nongovernment organizations
(NGOs), communities, beneficiaries, and bilateral and multilateral aid agencies in Sri Lanka.
The project design is summarized in the project framework in Appendix 1.
III.  BACKGROUND
A. Forest Sector in Sri Lanka
1. Sector Description
3. Sri Lanka’s national forests cover about 28 percent of the country’s 6.6 million hectares
(ha) land area, with 1.65 million ha under natural forests.3 These forests exhibit high levels of
diversity and some of the rarest plant species in the world are found in them. Dry-mixed
evergreen forests are the most widespread forest type in the country, and are home to some of
the poorest segments of the country’s population. Moreover, Sri Lanka’s forests play a crucial
role in maintaining soil, water, and nutrient cycles that support and sustain agriculture and allied
activities.
4. Over the last century, forests have been converted for agriculture, plantation corps,
shifting cultivation, and human settlements. Although commercial logging in the natural forests
was banned in early 1980s, population and development pressures have resulted in an annual
deforestation rate of 1.1 percent during 1990-1995; this rate is the second highest in South
Asia.4 Conflicting and unsound policies and undefined national forest boundaries have abetted
the land conversion, deforestation, and forest area fragmentation activities. The present forests
are  in  blocks  ranging  from  less  than  20  to  several  hundred  hectares,  with  a  few  blocks
measuring 10,000 ha or more. Several of the forests that are in urgent need of conservation are
not surveyed and thus are not legally gazetted (publicly recorded) and demarcated, thereby
limiting the effectiveness of efforts to conserve them. The fragmented and dispersed nature of
the forest area has overstretched the administrative and management capacity of the Forest
Department (FD).

5. The administration and management responsibilities for the national forest estate are
primarily shared by FD (1.06 million ha) and the Department of Wildlife Conservation (0.78 million
ha). Because many forestlands have been converted to other land uses, the traditional forest area
boundaries have become obsolete. Hence, FD’s administrative and managerial jurisdiction is not
well defined and this undermines its capacity to effectively protect and manage forests. FD’s
preoccupation with enforcement of timber transport regulations and centralized decision making
has resulted in inadequate attention to improving the productivity of the forests. Consequently, the
forests produce less than 1 cubic meter (m3) of wood per hectare per year. This is far less than
their full potential of 3-4 m3 per year. Low forest production has resulted in increasing shortages of
raw  materials  for  the  domestic  saw  milling  and  plywood  industries,  and  extraction  from
nonsustainable sources.
6. The Forestry Sector Master Plan (FSMP), developed in 1995, identified that wood for the
domestic saw milling, plywood, and manufacturing industries would be significantly lacking
within 10-15 years. Current industrial wood demand is estimated at 2.1million m3 of which 26
percent is imported. The plantation estate sector contributes 30 percent, home gardens 32
percent, and illegal logging from natural forests is estimated to account for 20-28 percent of the
domestic industrial wood supply. Industrial plantations contribute less than 10 percent to local
wood production, but supply the construction and furniture  manufacturing  sectors.  Present
trends in decreasing forest cover and wood supply clearly indicate present domestic sources
can not meet the demand.
7. Raw material supply problems of the wood industry are exacerbated by the monopolistic
role of the State Timber Corporation (STC), and perverse policies and regulations governing
transport of privately grown timber. This has resulted in poorly formed market channels and
linkages. STC’s de facto monopoly over harvesting, transporting, and marketing of logs from FD
plantations discourages private sector involvement in forestry. STC’s monopoly and inefficiencies
also cause high production costs and losses of wood harvested. Consequent wood shortages
contribute to overexploitation of the state forests.
8. In 1998, the forest sector contributed about 2 percent of gross domestic product (GDP),
and  primary  and  secondary  wood  industries  employed  about  60,000  people.  However,  the
contribution of the forest sector to national and local economies is not fully captured by the current
economic and financial accounting systems. For example, nonwood forest products have a role in
the rural economy. About 14 million rural people, or about 80 percent of the national population,
depend on forests to supply a wide range of such products. In the Knuckles region alone, on an
average, about 16 percent of the total family income is derived from such products. In some
places, cultivation of cardamom in the forests provides about 26 percent of the total family
income. The undervaluation of financial returns from the sector causes policy and decision-
makers to underestimate its revenue mobilization capacity. Sri Lanka’s forest sector has not
received the investment support commensurate with its development challenges.
9. In response to increased forestland conversion and increasing wood product demand,
Sri Lanka initiated in 1870s a plantation program that was intensified in the 1950s. To date,
135,000  hectares  of  plantations5  have  been  established  to  serve  environmental  and
developmental objectives. Because of declining areas of natural forests, the importance of
commercial plantations has increased. However, the plantations often suffer from insufficient
silvicultural management, resulting in suboptimal growth. Thus, the plantations realize less than
30 percent of their potential because of delays in harvesting caused by STC’s monopoly.
Consequently, STC is often unable to meet harvesting targets, and substantial wood production
and revenue are lost.

2. Rural Poverty in Sri Lanka
 10. Although Sri Lanka has strong social indicators compared with other countries in South
Asia, its incidence of poverty is high, with 21 percent of the total 18.8 million population still
living  in  poverty.  Despite  the  high  priority  that  the  Government  has  assigned  to  poverty
reduction in recent years, the number of poor people has not declined significantly. According to
the preliminary findings of the Government’s, ongoing poverty study,6 poverty is predominantly a
rural phenomenon in Sri Lanka, with over 85 percent of the poor in rural areas. Most of the poor
are concentrated in the provinces where agricultural growth has been slow due to adverse
agroecological conditions and insufficient infrastructure such as roads and markets. Malnutrition
is widespread especially among children and mothers. Sri Lanka’s food balance sheets for 1993
and 1994 show low per capita availability of calories, which is just above the recommended
minimum of 2,100 calories per day.
 
 11. Despite the introduction of the welfare-driven Samurdhi social safety net programs,7 Sri
Lanka does not have a specific poverty policy. The Government began its Poverty Reduction
Study in 1998, with a view to developing a comprehensive poverty framework for the country.
The Government is coordinating Sri Lanka’s first integrated survey of poverty, which will provide
valuable additional information about the household, social, and economic characteristics of
poverty. The Government’s framework for poverty reduction under the study advocates a three-
pronged strategy to achieve poverty reduction: (i) improving economic and social opportunities
for the poor, and broadening the range of people who benefit from growth; (ii) providing security
to people unable to participate in mainstream economic activities and protecting excluded,
marginalized, and vulnerable groups; and (iii) empowering people to have a voice in decision
making and development.
12. The  contributing  causes  of  poverty  in  the  rural  area  are  (i)  lack  of  remunerative
economic activities, associated with high levels of unemployment; and (ii) landlessness and lack
of secure land and tree tenure. The dry zone areas have the highest incidence of poverty in the
country. Near forest reserves in the dry zone, 38 percent of the population is below the poverty
line and 57 percent is just above it.8 Most of the households near forest reserves, regardless of
income, are on encroached lands. Where land is still available, most households engage in
shifting cultivation on state land that can supply 20 percent of the household income and
provide subsistence grain and vegetables. Communities near forest reserves in the dry zone
areas also depend on forest resources for self-employment activities. The condition in the wet
zone  areas  is  slightly  better.  Socioeconomic  surveys  show  that  households  near  forest
peripheries  receive  45-65  percent  of  their  income  from  tea.  Although  50  percent  of  the
households earn SLRs3,000-8,000 ($41-$109) per month in the wet zone areas, in some areas
13  percent  of  households  fall  below  the  poverty  line.  While  income  levels  are  definitely
correlated to landholding size, all income groups are found to have encroached on forestland,
and encroached upon lands account for 26 percent of total landholdings. Home gardens, which
are usually managed by women on encroached lands, are an important source of multiple
products, from fruit to minor export crops to wood.

13. In rural areas the poor are partly the cause, but are also the victims, of the forest
degradation  problem.  The  extent  and  patterns  of  dependence  on  the  forest  vary  among
communities,  depending  on  the  nature,  magnitude,  and  accessibility  of  forest  resources.
However, the primary dependence of certain forest communities, especially in the dry zone, on
a rapidly depleting resource is one of the major causes of deprivation. Poverty among the
communities  near  forest  reserves  has  increased  pressure  on  forest  resources  through
increased land encroachments, degradation, and deforestation. On the other hand, insecurity of
land rights for long-term use or lease arrangements over the encroached land has discouraged
many forest communities from making a long-term investment in the land. The inability of the
resource base to regenerate itself because of the heavy pressure of exploitation and uncertainty
of  land  rights  sets  up  a  resource  depletion-poverty  cycle,  which  reinforces  the  poverty-
environment degradation nexus.
14. Reducing poverty by meeting the legitimate needs of poor people dependent on forests
by providing income-earning opportunities, household energy, and fodder for cattle can break
this vicious cycle. In this context, security of tenure over forestland is a prerequisite for local
communities to participate in activities to ensure they share in the output.
15. NGOs9  in  Sri  Lanka  also  play  an  important  role  in  poverty  reduction.  They  help
implement afforestation and community development programs. Given their experience in rural
self-employment programs and the development of microenterprises, their services can be used
in poverty reduction programs to enhance community participation through social mobilization
and  training  of  poor  rural  communities.  Moreover,  NGOs  can  facilitate  the  formation  of
community-based organizations (CBOs) dedicated to poverty reduction and forest resource
management, and provide critical support to nascent CBOs of the rural poor, until they become
self-reliant.
B. Government Policies, Plans, and Programs
1. Strategic Framework, Policies, and Legislation
16. The Government has recognized that to solve the problem of the diminishing forest
resource base and the fragmented nature of the forest estate, the cooperation and participation
of  all  stakeholders  is  required  for  instituting  sustainable  forest  management.  Stakeholder
participation, especially of the local communities is essential for (i) establishing, delineating, and
enforcing forest area boundaries and thereby forest protection; (ii) increasing wood production
outside the state forests through social forestry programs, thereby increasing the production
base and easing the pressure on natural forests; and (iii) ensuring conservation of protected
areas. This shift from the traditional protectionist approach to a participatory one is essential to
ensure  that  the  management  systems  respond  to  the  needs  and  aspirations  of  the  local
communities, and reduce poverty by generating employment and income. To establish genuine
participatory forest management, stakeholder participation has to be secured for the Project’s
full planning and implementation cycle. This has to be complemented with secure tenurial
arrangements for sharing the benefits from the assets created. However, the implementation of
this strategy requires (i) transparency with regards to technical, financial, and administrative
aspects  of  development  interventions;  (ii)  full  accountability  of  all  actions  involved  in
implementing development activities; and (iii) institution of an independent monitoring system.

17. The adoption of the new National Forest Policy (NFP)10 in 1995 reflects government
commitment to policy and institutional reforms to institute participatory forest management. The
forest policy acknowledges concern for safeguarding the remaining natural forests for posterity.
It emphasizes the importance of retaining the present natural forest cover and increasing the
overall tree cover, and the need for an effective forest protected area system to conserve
biodiversity,  soil, and  water  resources.  The  production forests,  including  plantations  under
sustainable forest management, are to provide for the growing demand for forest products.
Furthermore,  the  NFP  recognizes  the  crucial  role  to  be  played  by  home  gardens  and
nonforestlands  through the use of social forestry and  agroforestry  technologies.  The  NFP
envisages broadening the institutional framework for forest management with clearly defined
roles  and  responsibilities for the forest  resource development partners.  The public  sector,
farmers, local communities, NGOs, and small- and medium-scale commercial entrepreneurs all
have a role in activities such as protecting the forests; growing trees to meet the wood and
bioenergy requirements; supplying raw material for wood-based industries; and harvesting,
transporting, processing, and marketing various forest products.
18. The  FSMP  conforms  to  the  spirit  of  the  NFP  by  providing  a  sector  development
framework  for  1995-2020.  The  FSMP  takes  into  account  lessons  learned  from  various
development programs, and emphasizes a participatory approach to address issues faced by
the forest sector. The lessons include  (i) ensuring that rural communities are empowered to
manage multiple-use forests for their own benefit; and (ii) in case of natural forests, striking a
better  balance  between  the  production  and  protection  functions  by  ensuring  participatory
sustainable  forest  management  is  practiced  by  all  willing  and  capable  stakeholders.  The
reorientation  accomplished  through  the  NFP  led  FD  to  develop  the  1997  Five-Year
Implementation Program (FYIP). The FYIP prescribes a balance between conservation and
sustainable forest management supported by public and private sector smallholder participation
in commercial forestry, and provided a sectoral implementation framework of the FSMP.
19. During the last three years, planned investment for implementation of the FYIP has been
delayed  by  limited  public  sector  financial  resources  and  delays  in  the  establishment  of
appropriate legislation and institutional reform to support the policy environment. The FYIP has
been  updated  and  renamed  the  Seven-Year  Implementation  Plan  (SYIP).  It  includes  a
development plan to facilitate investments in the sector by ADB and other interested funding
sources. The SYIP stresses the need to demarcate zone forestlands  as a prerequisite  to
programs dealing with forest resources management, biodiversity conservation, conservation of
soil and water resources, forest plantations, social and agroforestry development, and wood-
based industries. The FSMP and SYIP also highlight the need for private sector participation. In
response to ADB’s concerns, policies have been developed that will facilitate commercialization
of selected State operations, introduce a proper permit system for utilizing the forest resources,
reduce  and  refine  State  control,  and  confirm  proper  tenure  arrangements.  Implementing
legislation and institutional reforms (including restructuring and capacity building of FD) have
been developed and are currently in the process of being formalized. The SYIP also includes (i)
accelerating the development and implementation of forest management plans, (ii) creating
secure conditions for long-term investments by private firms in commercial forestry; and (iii)
deregulating the timber trade. The SYIP, which commences in the year 2000, provides an
appropriate framework for investment.

22. STC12 is responsible for the extraction of timber from state forests and plantations, and

23. As  enunciated  in  the  NFP,  the  Government  stresses  that  institutional  reforms  are

environmental conservation rather than sustained yield forest management. While NGOs are
large organizations with national level presence and local-level branches, CBOs are localized

helped implement afforestation and community development programs. Given their experience

through  social  mobilization  and  training  of  poor  rural  communities.  Moreover,  NGOs  can
facilitate the formation of CBOs dedicated to poverty reduction and environmental management,

C. External Assistance to the Sector
26. Since 1975, the forest sector of Sri Lanka has received an estimated $100 million of
bilateral and multilateral assistance. Major sources of assistance have included ADB, the World
Bank, the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and bilateral aid agencies such as
the United States Agency for International Development (USAID); the Overseas Development

Kingdom (UK); the Finnish International Development Agency (FINNIDA); and the Australian
Agency  for  International  Development  (AusAID).  The  focus  of  external  assistance  was
conventional  reforestation  in  1980s,  which  gradually  shifted  in  the  1990s  to  sustainable
management  of  forest  resources  through  participatory  approaches,  while  strengthening
institutional capacities of FD.
27. ADB's assistance began in 1982 with the Community Forestry Project.13 The project,
which was successfully completed in 1991, aimed at addressing the problem of declining forest
resources by conventional reforestation in a block plantation program and a small social forestry
component involving tree cultivation by rural communities. 8,100 ha of block plantations and
1,200 ha of farmers' woodlots were established. This was followed by the ongoing Participatory
Forestry Project.14 This project increased production of forest and tree products, enhanced
employment opportunities and income, and rehabilitated environmentally degraded areas in the
country through beneficiaries’ participation. AusAID cofinanced the project in the form of food
aid paid to farmers as compensation for time spent in tree planting and maintenance activities.
ADB’s Upper Watershed Management Project15 addresses the forest and land degradation and
poverty  in  the upper  watersheds by  increasing forest  cover  in  critical  watersheds  through
integrated and participatory approaches, with the added objective of increasing productivity and
small-scale farmers’ income by promoting conservation-oriented farming systems.
28. External assistance  (Appendix  2)  has  also  played  an  important  role  in  the  sector,
particularly in the development of the Forestry Master Plan in 1983, funded by the World Bank
and FINNIDA. In 1991, the World Bank, FINNIDA, DFID, and UNDP provided assistance to the
Forestry  Sector  Development  Project  to  help  the  Government  improve  forestry  sector
performance in line with Sri Lanka's economic, social, and environmental requirements by
developing and implementing a five-year portion of the FSMP.

E. ADB's Sectoral Strategy
30. ADB's Country Operational Strategy for Sri Lanka (1998)17 recommends that sustainable
natural resources management should be one of the key areas for ADB’s involvement to reduce
poverty and ensure long-term sustainability of economic growth. Criteria that will guide ADB's
interventions include (i) achieving a balance between the economic and ecological functions of
the environment, (ii) addressing poverty-related causes of environmental degradation, and (iii)
preventing and minimizing economic damage to existing environmental infrastructure. Forest
and biodiversity conservation and management are focal areas for ADB’s assistance, together
with sustainable development and management of coastal  resources  and  integrated  water
resource management.
31. ADB's policy on forestry encompasses three basic principles: protection, production, and
participation. Based on these principles, ADB’s assistance stresses activities that (i) enhance
protective functions of forests with respect to soil, water, and biodiversity; (ii) carry out cost
effective  and  sustainable  harvesting  of  natural  and  plantation  forests;  and  (iii)  promote
involvement  of  affected  communities  in  the  formulation  and  implementation  of  forestry
development activities. Focus on interventions to reduce poverty as ADB’s overarching goal has
been highlighted in natural resources management projects and enhanced through employment
of participatory approaches. Based on these considerations, the Project has been designed
primarily to improve livelihoods of poor rural people.
F. Policy Dialogue
32. The Government has formulated and adopted the NFP and gained experience from
implementing ADB-assisted forestry projects. The Government and ADB agrees that policy and
institutional  reforms  with  an  enabling  legislative  framework  are  necessary  to  facilitate
implementation of the NFP. Priority actions in this context include (i) the deregulation of permits

IV. THE PROPOSED PROJECT
A.  Rationale
40. Poverty among forest dependent communities is closely linked with deforestation, land
degradation, and land and tree tenure  insecurities. Causes  of  poverty  in forest-dependent
communities in the rural areas include unclear forest boundaries leading to insecure land and
tree tenure, inadequate technical and extension capacity of the FD, and government decision
makers’  lack  of  awareness  about  the  value  of  the  forests  to  livelihood  improvement  and
economic development. Because people do not have secure land and tree tenures, they do not
make long-term investments in forest and tree growing, and  limit  their  participation  in  the
management of forest resources that affect their life. The Project will help reduce deforestation
and  degradation of  lands  and  soils  on  which  these  communities  depend  for  subsistence.
Moreover,  strengthening  of  FD’s  extension  and  technical  capacities,  in  conjunction  with
boundary demarcation and integrated forest management, will increase their income generating
opportunities.  The  Project’s  participatory  approach  will  ensure  participation  of  forest
communities,  NGOs,  and  CBOs.  This  will  accelerate  the  participatory  forest  resource

11
development and environmental awareness in which local communities see themselves as the
beneficiaries of the process. Close consultation and participation of local communities in forest
demarcation  and  delineation,  together  with  the  reform  in  long-term  forestland  lease
arrangements, will help create security of tenure for the poor households and in turn, will
encourage a long-term productive investment.
41. FD’s  current  organizational  structure  and  decision-making  procedures  emphasize
administration and policing, which limits community participation in forest management. FD’s
preoccupation with administering a dispersed and undemarcated estate on its own has resulted
in piecemeal efforts being made to improve forest management and productivity. Furthermore,
the STC monopoly on timber harvesting, and timber transport regulations, have discouraged
private sector and local communities from becoming full partners in increasing production and
improving the management of the forest estate.
42.   The  FSMP  lays  out  the  long-term  sector  development  priorities  and  investment
strategies.  This  is  complemented  by  the  new  NFP,  which  emphasizes  participatory  forest
management principles and is in line with ADB’s forest sector policy. However, to implement the
sector  approach  and  to  institutionalize  participatory  sustainable  forest  management,
comprehensive  policy,  regulatory,  and  institutional  reforms  are  required  and  must  be
complemented by clear delineation and demarcation of the national forest areas.
43. Moreover, to reduce poverty among the forest dependent communities, investments will
be needed to provide them with secure land and tree tenure. This effort can be strengthened by
delineating and demarcating of permanent forest estate, implementing institutional reforms to
improve governance and performance of the forest sector by enhancing community and private
sector participation, and upgrading FD’s operational and technological capacities for improved
forest protection and production.
B. Objectives and Scope
44. The overall goal of the Project is to increase the value and sustainability of Sri Lanka’s
forests. The goal is to be achieved by creating a policy and governance framework that enables
participation of local communities and the private sector in forest resource development and
management.  The  objectives  of  the  proposed  Project  are  to  (i)  establish  and  implement
participatory sustainable forest management of demarcated permanent forests, to increase their
protection and production; and (ii) enhance access of the local communities (in particular, the
economically disadvantaged people) to gainful employment and human resource development
opportunities, leading to poverty reduction.
45. The Project will cover 17 of the 19 existing territorial forest divisions. If the security
situation improves, the Project will be extended to cover the remaining two divisions. The
Project will support the first part of FSMP, to be implemented during seven years. The Project
will include activities aimed at implementing the NFP. Consistent with a sector approach and the
NFP, the Project will help the Government improve forest sector governance by establishing
legal and functional boundaries of the forest areas. This will allow improved management and
protection. At the same time, timber transport and trade will be deregulated; the STC monopoly
on harvesting timber on state forestlands will be phased out; and local communities and the
private  sector  will  be  involved  in  rehabilitation,  regeneration,  and  management  of  state
forestlands and plantations.
46. The Project will be implemented in about 10 subproject areas (SPAs), each covering up
to three forestry divisions. A comprehensive study was successfully concluded in three core-
SPAs (Anuradhapura, Badulla and Nuwara Eliya,  and  Ratnapura) during  the TA  identified

12
intervention packages for implementation under the Project. These interventions are equally
applicable to the additional seven SPAs that have been selected. However, the work and its
phasing will be tailored to specific needs and requirements of each SPA. Most SPAs conform to
the existing forest division boundaries, although divisions with similar agroecological features
have been combined to form a single SPA to ensure consistency with an integrated ecosystem
management approach. The other criteria for the constitution and selection of the SPAs include
(i)  the  interventions  within  each  subproject  must  be  compatible  with  the  overall  project
objectives  and  interventions  in  the  core  SPAs;  (ii)  beneficiary  communities  must  have
established their willingness and ability to participate; (iii) land ownership must not be disputed;
(iv) each component must be technically feasible; (v) the areas for specific interventions must
be accessible; (vi) most potential beneficiaries should belong to landless and/or low income
households and should be willing and able to participate; (vii) each subproject must have an
economic internal rate of return of at least 12 percent; and (viii) the potential environmental
impacts  must  be  within  acceptable  levels  as  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s
environmental guidelines,19 and should include the provision for mitigation, if necessary. FD will
approve the remaining subproject feasibility reports as long as they are in conformity with the
criteria.
47. The Project consists of three components; (i) participatory forest planning, management,
and  awareness;  (ii)  sustainable  forest  resource  development  and  management;  and  (iii)
institutional strengthening for improved sector performance.
1. Participatory Forest Planning, Management, and Awareness
a.  Delineation, Demarcation, Survey, and Mapping
48. In the 17 forest divisions covered, the Project will support surveying and demarcating
boundaries with the close consultation, and participation of local communities. A total of 17,500
kilometers (km) of surveying and demarcation will be completed to establish permanent forest
areas and facilitate integrated forest resource management planning and implementation. The
initial estimates of the total periphery of the forest areas are 13,000 km for natural forests and
4,500 km for the forest plantations, with priority given to the demarcation of blocks exceeding 20
ha. The procedure for surveying will involve community consultation to obtain a consensus
about the locations of forest boundaries. Concrete boundary pillars will then be installed. Next,
the survey maps and records will be updated. Consistent with the NFP management categories,
FD will produce forest type and management maps based on the results of the participatory
forest planning and demarcation process.
b. Integrated Management Planning
49. The SYIP will be implemented at the forest division level. The Project  will  support
preparation of IFRMPs by FD in consultation with the participating stakeholders. IFRMPs will
include  forest  mapping,  classification,  assessment  of  growing  stocks  and  assessments  of
forests in terms of species diversity, as a basis for determining principal management regimes,
practices, and annual harvesting levels. Moreover, IFRMPs will be developed for each forest
management  unit.  IFRMP  preparation  will  be  complemented  by  workshops  for  local
communities and key provincial agencies, to link district development plans and land resource
development initiatives to forest sector needs and priorities.

2. Sustainable Forest Resource Development and Management
52. The Project  will  support  field  interventions  that  are  technically  appropriate,  socially

and non-degraded forestlands, (ii) participatory rehabilitation and management of protected

a. Participatory Forest Resource Development and Management
i. Community-Based Agroforestry and Social Forestry
Development
53. The proposed agroforestry woodlot model will help reestablish permanent tree cover on
shifting cultivation forestlands by improving tenurial rights. The Project will help the participants
secure long-term lease that cover at least 1 harvest cycle (rotation), provide tree seedlings for
growing timber and fruit trees in combination with agriculture crops, and fund labor costs for tree
planting and maintenance over a two-year period. Beneficiaries will ensure protection and long-
term  maintenance  of  the  woodlots  during  the  first  rotation,  and  will  be  responsible  for
establishing the trees for a second rotation. FD will receive 20 percent of the final harvest from
the first rotation, to pay for woodlot establishment costs. Use of the agroforestry model will
increase  the  functional  boundaries  of  the  forest  estate;  enrich  local  agroecosystems;  and
diversify product and income streams, thus increasing the income to the local communities. The
species mix and technical specifications to be developed during the participatory  land-use
planning exercise will be tailored to maximize benefits to women and other household workers
who currently contribute most of the labor to land management activities. CBOs/NGOs will
facilitate the exercise for households that have a lease agreement.
54. This model is estimated to be implemented on 8,600 ha of smallholder agroforestry
woodlots. Of this area, about 2,500 ha are in the core SPAs with an indicative target of 6,100 ha
in the additional SPAs. An estimated 7,500 households will benefit from the activity. Households
headed by women will participate through participatory land-use planning, decision making

about species mix and management regimes, secure land and usufruct tenurial agreements in
their names, and preferential targeting of project inputs such as FD’s extension assistance. FD
will use these sites as demonstration models to extend improved coppicing and tree tending
techniques.
ii. Improved Management of Existing Woodlots
55. The Project will assist approximately 8,000 farmers to increase their ability to generate
income from existing woodlots by providing support for establishment of long-term tenure to
their plots. This support will include surveying of boundaries, their registration with FD, and
provision  of  technical  extension  and  marketing  to  support  improved  decision  making  to
maximize the value of existing crops and returns from the reforestation program. To reinforce
and institutionalize FD’s forestry extension capacity, Regional Forest Officers will develop a
planned and programmed extension package for woodlot lessees. The Project will support the
development of demonstration plots on selected woodlots where farmers will be able to “learn
by doing” woodlot maintenance and management. The Project will provide technical extension
materials and manuals for distribution to participating farmers (including wall charts, marketing
information services, and techniques for estimating the value of tree crops). The extension
materials will be developed for both teak and eucalyptus woodlots. The total scope for improving
existing woodlot management is 7,300 ha, of which about 2,500 ha is estimated to be in core
SPAs and 4,800 ha in the additional SPAs. The assistance to be provided by the consultants
will aim at increasing the plantation productivity and financial returns on investment.
iii. Rehabilitation and Management of Degraded Plantations
56. Local  CBOs  and  beneficiaries  will  be  encouraged  to  convert  FD’s  unproductive
plantations into financially viable plantations. The Project includes the extraction of existing
commercial grade  timber or fuelwood,  and  reestablishment of  plantations  with  appropriate
species mix and adequate post-planting maintenance. A total of 12,600 ha (equivalent to 40
percent of the current area of productive plantations) will be rehabilitated and converted into
productive  and  financially  viable  plantations.  Site  preparation,  including  felling  and  stump
removal, will be bid out competitively. The core SPAs have about 3,800 ha of such sites, and
the additional SPAs about 8,800 ha more.
b. Participatory Rehabilitation and Management of Protected Forests
i. Buffer Zone Development for Multiple-Use Forestry
57. The Project will support intensification of agricultural production and enhanced farm
incomes in encroached areas as a means to reduce forest conversion. The Project will support
the delivery of extension services from appropriate agencies, development of community-based
participatory land-use planning, building of conflict management capacity through provision of
facilitators, and group processes.  Existing  CBOs  will  be  fully  involved  in  such  processes.
Wherever  CBOs  cannot  be  found,  experienced  NGOs  will  be  involved  in  mobilizing  the
communities  and  facilitating  farmer  participation.  Assessing  the  potential  uses  of  natural
resources will be supported to determine allowable harvest levels and to develop strategies for
buffer zone land and biomass resource development. The Project will support such activities on
about 2,800 ha (1,400 ha in core SPAs and about 1,400 ha in the additional SPAs).

ii. Enrichment Planting20 and Management of Protection and
Other Natural Forests
58. The Project will support FD’s conservation operations and protection of the natural
forests. This will include increased forest protection to encourage natural regeneration, and
enrichment planting with appropriate species to enhance forest diversity. Under this component,
enrichment  planting  will  be  carried  out  in  areas  where,  due  to  reduced  rainfall  and/or
degradation,  natural  regeneration  may  not  occur.  In  these  areas,  the  Project  will  support
enrichment planting of appropriate species and monitor their development to identify the most
promising species for natural forest restoration. This component is estimated to cover 1,300 ha
(400 ha in the core SPAs and about 900 ha in additional SPAs).
c. Production Forest Management
i. Improvement, Rehabilitation, and Management of Degraded
Plantations
59. The Project will support FD to (i) upgrade existing and introduce new technologies for
improved planting stock production; harvesting techniques; and forest stand establishment,
rehabilitation, and maintenance; and (ii) improve stand regeneration and restoration practices
for  establishing  and  managing  commercially  viable  plantations.  To  ensure  adequate
regeneration and return on investments, and acceptable growth rates and yields, the Project will
support three years of post planting maintenance. The Project will also support the import of
seeds for improving the planting stock. Private sector participation in stand maintenance and
harvesting will be facilitated using open tender systems to improve the cost effectiveness,
accountability,  and  transparency  of  forestry  operations.  The  Project  will  support  the
development of open tendering systems and train private sector contractors in the forestry
codes of practice to be adopted by FD. Harvesting techniques that reduce waste, including
directional felling, will be employed. The total scope under this component is 5,600 ha (1,800 ha
in core SPAs and 3,800 additional SPAs).
ii. Private Sector Pilot Leasehold Management of
State Plantations
60. The Project will facilitate pilot-level private sector investment in the management and
development of state forest plantations. The Project will facilitate the transfer of management
rights (including rights to harvest the existing stock) of plantations from FD to the private sector.
The areas to be transferred will be identified during IFRMP feasibility studies and private sector
entities will be responsible for reestablishing and maintaining second rotation crops. The Project
will facilitate the involvement of up to five private sector entities, each to manage no less than
1,000 ha of existing plantations and 200 ha of degraded plantations.
61. The Project  will  support  FD  in  the development of  legal  documentation,  tendering,
transfer of assets, development of environmental safeguards and guidelines, and development
of monitoring and evaluation processes. This will include the development of prequalification
techniques, development of an appropriate tendering and negotiation process, preparation of
bid documentation, and the establishment of holding companies as appropriate. A total area of
6,000 ha is included in this activity (about 2,400 ha in core SPAs and 3,600 ha in additional
SPAs).

3.  Beneficiary Participation
73. Beneficiary participation and bottom-up planning have been incorporated in the project
design to ensure full commitment and ownership by potential beneficiaries of the development

Ongoing  forestry  projects  and  pilot  projects  show  that  farmers  benefit  most  through  their
participation in project planning and implementation. Participating  farmers  know that  these
activities  will  deliver sustainable  benefits  to  them,  although  not  immediately  after  the  tree
planting. The Project will provide financial incentives to the beneficiaries by providing them with
seeds, seedlings, fertilizers, and extension information that has proven to be successful in
enhancing the active participation of beneficiaries. Qualified CBOs/NGOs will be engaged by
RPIUs to assist the active participation of beneficiaries. Criteria for selecting CBOs and NGOs

4.  Subsidies
74. The Project will provide incentives or subsidies amounting to $6.0 million  (15 percent of
the total cost) to farmers. The inputs for planting and maintaining trees on public land will be
provided free of charge, and farmers will be paid for their labor. Cost of the incentives will be
recovered in full through the sale of harvested trees on the basis of the cost-sharing formula
agreed between the beneficiaries and FD. The subsidies are essential to encourage land and
resource poor farmers to participate in the project implementation, and will have no recurrent
budgetary implications, as these will be terminated upon the completion of the Project. The
subsidies are justified because (i) most trees are to be planted on Government land and at a
cost  20-30  percent  lower  than  that  of  the  traditional  reforestation  approaches;  (ii)  the
environmental benefits of the Project in terms of increased soil and water conservation will
exceed the cost of the subsidies; and (iii) a substantial proportion of the subsidized activities
involve beneficiaries who are living below the poverty line and can not donate their labor at this
stage.

and institutional reform, and monitoring. FD is responsible for forestry management. Both MFE
and FD have satisfactorily implemented several externally funded projects. MFE is the core
agency for environmental protection and natural resource management. MFE has staff with
experience in externally assisted projects. MFE has developed the SYIP that corresponds to
part of the  FSMP; proposed promulgation  of  a forestry  ordinance  to  implement  the  NFP;
successfully implemented participatory and community forestry projects; and is implementing
watershed conservation projects. Thus, MFE has demonstrated the  required  technical and
managerial  capability  to  implement  a  sector  project  to  meet  the  development  and  forest
conservation challenges faced by the country.
91. However, MFE and FD traditional structures and procedures emphasize a top-down and
centralized approach to forest sector development and decision making. The emphasis has
been on protection and regulatory functions rather than improving the overall performance of the
forest  sector.  MFE  has  had  limited  impact  on  influencing  the  cross-sectoral  policies  that
adversely impact forest conservation and development. FD’s current operational structures and
practices provide limited opportunity for practicing participatory forestry. Furthermore, frontline
forestry staff, who are often more in tune with the needs and challenges of forestry, have limited
decision making powers and thus often can not be proactive and innovative in their functioning.
G.  Environmental and Social Measures
1.  The Environment
92. The  Project  is  classified  under  environmental  category  B.  An  initial  environmental
examination (IEE) was undertaken in accordance with ADB’s environmental guidelines.22 The
IEE shows that no significant adverse environmental impact is anticipated and that a detailed
environmental impact assessment is not required. The IEE also shows that the project design
will improve the quality of the environment and the welfare of the people living in the project
area. Among the Project’s positive contributions to the environment are (i) reduced soil erosion,
(ii)  reduced  sedimentation of  reservoirs,  (iii)  increased  conservation  of  natural forests  and
wildlife  sanctuaries,  (iv)  increased  coverage  of  plantation  forests,  (v)  increased  fuelwood
production, (vi) better land-use planning, and (vii) efficient land tenure rights. The summary IEE
(Appendix 9) was prepared and endorsed by the Government.
93. The three core SPAs represent the major ecological zones in Sri Lanka: the dry zone
(Anuradhapura district), montane zone (Badulla and Nuwara Eliya districts), and wet  zone
(Ratnapura district). The three core SPAs demonstrate the different degrees and  types  of
dependence of the communities on the forest reserves that subsequently reflect their levels of
and strategies to cope with poverty.
2.  Social Measures

district. Farmers in the dry zone have fewer economic alternatives to escape poverty than

95. The full participation of women will be needed to make any changes of land use in and
around forest reserves. The Project will actively seek women’s input in the integrated forest

96. Project interventions have been designed to encourage the communities to see the need
for  reducing  forest  exploitation  and  adopting  conservation  measures.  Public  awareness

(ii) rice irrigation, and (iii) creation of beneficial microclimates for tea production. At the same
time the Project will demonstrate that additional income can be generated through improved
management  of  the forest  reserves  and  long-term  investment  in  the  existing  smallholding

V.  PROJECT JUSTIFICATION
A. Economic and Financial Analyses
1.  Economic Analysis
97. Economic analysis was carried out for the three core SPAs, which represent the major
agroecological zones and are considered to be representative of the wider project area. To
quantify costs and benefits associated with the distinct physical characteristics of each SPA, the

buffer zones and forest reserves, (iv) enrichment of protection plantations, (v) rehabilitation of
degraded FD plantations, (vi) improved management of teak and eucalyptus plantations, and
(vii) pilot private sector concessionaires.  All costs and benefits have been divided into tradable
and nontradable components. The former is expressed in border prices and the latter in the
value of foreign exchange. The border prices were estimated from domestic prices using a
standard conversion factor of 0.9. The analysis is undertaken using with and without project

98. The costs at the subproject level include those incurred in the physical development of
the  field  interventions,  including  extension  inputs,  planting  and  labor,  survey  and  lease
agreements,  and  marketing.  In  addition,  costs  of  the  intermediate  services  and  goods
(component 1) required to successfully implement the Project along with the prerequisite human
resource development and institutional strengthening (component 3) are apportioned to the core
SPAs (35 percent) and the additional SPAs (65 percent) based on the relative proportion of field
interventions. A standard conversion factor was applied to domestic prices in line with recent
ADB estimates. The opportunity cost of labor was derived from applying a shadow wage rate
factor of 0.8 to unskilled labor, which was converted to border prices by applying the standard
conversion factor.24
99. Direct and indirect benefits are included. The direct benefits are realized on-site, such as
the  value  of  incremental  output  of  commercial  logs  and  poles  and  of  limited  agricultural
production. The indirect benefits are limited to the enrichment of protection forests in the upland
agroecological zone and include the loss of hydroelectric generating capacity based on past
local data sets. Where appropriate, income foregone is included as a negative benefit to reflect
the without project scenario. Several benefits are not quantified due to the paucity of data.
These include the value of additional carbon sequestration and the intrinsic value of habitat
saved from ongoing conversion to agricultural use. Carbon sequestration can be estimated but
there is little indication of a willingness to pay for the carbon sequestering potential within Sri
Lanka. Habitat values have been estimated for lowland wet zone forests; however these are not
likely to reflect the average willingness to pay for lesser-known sites in Sri Lanka. Without a
substantial research project there is inadequate data to assign such values. The project benefits
will accrue from sustainable forest management that will provide logs, poles, and agricultural
crops. Border prices were used for valuing logs and were adjusted for transport and handling
charges.

from 13 percent for Badulla and Nuwara Eliya to 20 percent for Ratnapura. The variation reflects

planting in the Ratnapura SPA. Details are shown in Appendix 11.

local community members who have little or knowledge on silviculture or marketing of trees;

3. Risks
 
 103. The  major  risks  to  the  Project  are  (i)  delays,  and  noncompliance  with  policy  and
institutional reforms needed for better sector performance, (ii) failure of potential beneficiaries to
actively participate, and (iii) inefficient coordination between relevant government agencies.
104. Specific safeguards against these risks have been incorporated in the Project design.
For (i), some reforms may not be easily carried out due to the lack of understanding among
people and political resistance from vested interest groups. This risk will be minimized through
an effective awareness and extension campaign. The Project includes assistance to establish a
media unit and undertake an awareness and extension program to establish a constituency of
beneficiaries,  NGOs,  CBOs,  and  civil  society  to  demand  adherence  to  the  policy  and
institutional reforms. It was agreed that public awareness campaign and extension program will
be undertaken within 6 months after loan effectiveness. Furthermore, frequent policy dialogue
and close monitoring of the time- bound policy and institutional reforms and timely corrective
action from ADB will minimize this risk. For (ii), the extension programs and financial incentives
will facilitate beneficiaries’ participation. NGOs and CBOs are expected to play an important role
in promoting the participatory approach to minimize the risk. For (iii), project implementation will
be carried out through several coordination mechanisms. Through close consultation among
relevant agencies the NPIU and DCC at the field level will serve as effective coordination
bodies. MFE is experienced with coordinating various activities. Relevant agencies, including
MFE and FD, have recognized that illegal logging and the high demand for industrial wood
contribute to forest depletion and have taken strong measures to avoid overexploitation by
commercial interests. This matter will be discussed during the coordination meetings.
B. Environment
105. The Project is designed to enhance the environmental conditions of the core SPAs,25
and  is  to  be  undertaken  through  participatory  and  bottom-up  planning  approaches.  The
environmental  impact  screening  has  not  identified  any  significant  adverse  environmental
impacts. Minor adverse impacts under the commercial forest management, which far outweigh
the benefits, can easily be mitigated.
106. The  main  benefits  expected  from  the  protection  forestry  interventions  and  public
awareness  and  extension  services  in  the  wet  zone  are  (i)  biodiversity,  soil,  and  water
conservation in southwest Sri Lanka, an area with an unusually high concentration of species
and with exceptionally high levels of endemism and over 95 percent of the country’s threatened
plant and animal species; (ii) global importance for the conservation of the world’s floristic
diversity  in  the  highly  threatened  area  of  southwest  Sri  Lanka;  (iii)  the  awareness  of
conservation among peripheral communities of protection and conservation forests and the
general public; and (iv) publication of information relevant to conservation and biodiversity.

107. Reforestation provides a range of environmental benefits and services. Increasing tree
cover can increase soil fertility by improving moisture retention, soil structure, and nutrient
content. Tree cover helps to reduce rapid runoff of rainwater, thereby regulating stream flow and
improving  water  quality  by  reducing  sediment  in  surface  waters.  Incorporating  trees  into
agricultural systems can improve crop yields by improving soil and the microclimate.
108. Commercial plantation activities provide increased revenue to the Government, private
sector involvement in plantation activities, and a continuous supply of wood from plantations.
Agroforestry  woodlot  activities  will  reduce  the  area  under  shifting  cultivation  and  provide
permanent supplementary income to farmers. Improvements to existing farmer woodlots will
increase the quality and quantity of wood coming to the market. The project interventions will
improve the protection, conservation, and management of forests urgently needing protection by
reducing or halting the encroachments and illicit felling of timber. The Project will also increase
the awareness of conservation among peripheral communities and in the general public. If the
Project is not implemented, the degradation of resources in these forest reserves will continue.
The proposed restructuring of FD will allow efficient management of forest resources in the
country, which will contribute to the protection of the environment.
109. The sustainable management of dry zone forest  reserves under the  social forestry
interventions  will  increase  the  benefit  flow  to  surrounding  communities.  Land  leased  for
agroforestry woodlots will provide continued income to the farmers and discourage shifting
cultivation. Improved management of existing woodlots will provide incentives for continued
smallholder management.
C. Impacts on Poverty
110. The Project will benefit about 50,000 households and directly generate about 6 million
person-days of work for the rural sector. It will have an impact on reducing poverty in the rural
area, where 35 percent of the population live under the poverty line. The Project will increase
employment and income generation opportunities through increasing the activities within the
forest and allied sectors. In rural communities, livelihood adjacent to forest reserves will be
supported in order to stabilize land use and create greater tenurial certainty over land and trees.
In Anuradhapura, approximately 2,500 marginal and landless women and men will receive long-
term leases to FD land for agroforestry plots and farmer woodlots (2,500 ha). The provision of
supplemental  income  from  the  wood  portion  of  these  plots  helps  to  reduce  household
vulnerability during years of poor rainfall. About 2,500 farmers with woodlots will benefit from
training and marketing activities, and will thus increase their income. An annual increase of
household income is estimated at SLRs1,000-2,000 ($14-27) depending on the agroforestry
model.
111. The forest reserve buffer zone development intervention will be implemented in critical
communities of Ratnapura wet zone district to provide financial training and alternatives to
expanding the tea garden areas. Assistance for savings mobilization and access to existing
financial institutions is expected to help tea smallholders manage their finances for other income
generating activities. Additional interventions in Ratnapura include rehabilitation of degraded
plantations (1,250 ha) and enrichment and management of protection forests (400 ha), which
will have a long-term impact on increasing income and reducing poverty.
112.  A  total of about 50,000 beneficiary  household  will  directly benefit  from  the  Project
through participation in the reforestation activities. Of the households in core SPAs, 40-65
percent are below  the  poverty  line  and  will  benefit  from  improved  productive  activities  in
forestlands, where they will have greater security of tenure, and from employment opportunities
generated by the Project. By deregulating the sector operations and adopting multistakeholder

and  community-based  resource  development  and  management,  the  Project  will  help  the
Government improve the governance of the sector by making all parties involved in the forest
sector  more  accountable.  Furthermore,  the  operating  procedures  and  implementation
arrangements will ensure transparency. More importantly, institutionalization of participatory
forestry management will help make benefit-sharing from forest resources more accessible to
the local poor and improve the socioeconomic status of the local communities. This will enable
them to  maximize  their  chances for  being  able to  access and  influence  the  development
programs and projects that can enhance their livelihoods.
VI. ASSURANCES
A.  Specific Assurances
113.  The specific assurances are as follows:
(i) MFE  and  FD,  in  consultation  with  the  Survey  Department  of  the  Ministry  of
Agriculture  and  Lands,  will  prepare  a  time-bound  operational  plan  to  survey,
delineate,  demarcate,  map,  and  redraw  forest  boundaries  using  agreed  upon
ecological criteria, and the MFE and FD will ensure that a management unit that
contains similar prescriptions is not split as a result of the demarcation.
(ii)  During 2001, 2002, and 2003, STC will have guaranteed access to state forest
plantations with annual harvesting rights over 1,200 ha (the level earmarked for
2000) provided the area harvested by STC during 2001, equals or exceeds 1,200 ha
allocation. If STC is unable to meet the 2001 harvesting target, the annual allocation
for 2002 and 2003 will be limited to the maximum area that STC harvested during
2001. Free and open competitive bidding for the remaining area (not less than 600
ha in 2002 and 2003) that is available for harvesting under the existing management
plans or the IFRMPs, is to be made available to STC and the private sector equally,
in accordance with open and competitive bidding procedures. At the end of 2003,
STC’s special allocation of harvesting rights will be reviewed by an independent
committee comprising a multidisciplinary team of experts selected in consultation
with ADB, with the objective of enhancing private sector participation.
(iii)  The  Borrower  will  issue  long-term  lease/management-rights  to  all  participating
farmers in the woodlots program, and ensure that (a) the CF has delegated power to
issue  leases  over  state  land;  (b)  until  the  delegation  is  formalized,  the  Land
Commissioner will facilitate the leasing process; and (c) for private sector leasehold
management  of  state  forest  plantations  rules  and  procedures  in  line  with  the
National Forestry Policy are adopted and formalized.
(iv)  MFE  will  (a)  undertake  a  thorough  public  awareness  campaign  for  forestry
management  and  deregulation;  (b)  deregulate  nationally,  timber  and  wood
harvesting and transport for agreed species found on private lands, in the agreed
phased manner, with an annual review conducted jointly; (c) eliminate excess stock
examinations of all private wood enterprises by the end of 2001; and (d) conduct a
review by end of 2003 for deregulation of jak timber harvesting and transport with
the Ministry of Agriculture and Lands.
(v)  By 31 December 2001, the Borrower will submit to Parliament, a bill to amend or
replace the Forest Ordinance and will approve associated regulations to bring the
legislative framework in line with the imperatives and strategies enunciated in the
National Forest Policy.

A.  Asian Development Bank (ADB) Projects in Sri Lanka
1.  Community Forestry Project
1. The Community Forestry Project,1 with $10.0 million financed by ADB, was completed in
1991.  This  project  aimed  at  supplying  Sri  Lanka  with  needed  fuelwood  and  timber  from
conventional reforestation in block plantations and a small social forestry component designed
to  pursue  tree  cultivation  through  community  involvement.  The  Country  Synthesis  of
Postevaluation in Sri Lanka2 rated the project as generally successful. The report concluded that
the project had made positive ecological impacts, including soil conservation, stabilization of
hydrological systems, and creation of wind shelters.
2. The project concept was sound, with a lower risk plantation component being combined
with a more innovative community forestry component. However, community participation in
reforestation can only be fully achieved if the community is involved throughout the project cycle
including the planning and monitoring phase. Tree planting can conflict with peak agricultural
activities,  which  should  be  considered  when  scheduling  implementation  and  determining
compensation. Individual farm households need immediate compensation, such as food for
work, to enable them to undertake tree cultivation, particularly during peak season for work on
agricultural crops. To assure the needed level and means of community participation in a
reforestation project, appropriate disciplinary expertise must be employed during the preparation
of the feasibility study and appraisal. Participating families need secure rights and benefits to
harvest final products with appropriate lease/management agreement.

C. Lessons Learned and their Incorporation in the Project
1. Deregulation of Forest Related Activities
11. Many  forest-related  activities,  including  transportation  of  timbers  and  harvesting  of
considerable  numbers  of  species  grown  on  private  land,  are  currently  subject  to  strict
regulations. Deregulation should be promoted to enable the field-level FD staff to be more
actively involved in forest resource management activities with local communities, rather than in
legal enforcement activities.
12. The Government agreed that regulation of timber and wood felling would be phased out
with specified time-bound targets. The targets specify the names and numbers of species that
will be exempt from permits nationwide at the agreed time. In year three, the jak felling and
transport will be deregulated and the findings of the review used to guide the decision making
about possible deregulation of felling jackfruit trees. The Project, at the same time, will support
the development of media capacity and campaigns for public awareness about the benefits of
deregulation and other policy reforms.
2. Delineation and Demarcation of the State Forests
13. Ambiguousness in the boundaries of state forests has encouraged encroachment and
illicit harvesting. Clear delineation and demarcation of the forests and appropriate legislation is
imperative for more efficient and effective enforcement forest boundaries and to protect the
remaining natural forest. This is also a prerequisite for planning and implementing integrated
forest resources management.
14. A  bill  will  be  introduced  in  the  Parliament  to  amend  or  replace  the  1907  Forest
Ordinance and approve associated regulations with provisions for classification forests under
FD’s jurisdiction. The Project will support the demarcation of legal boundaries on the ground
through the surveying and demarcation of the forest in close consultation and participation of
local communities. A total of 17,500 km of surveying and demarcation will be completed to
establish a permanent forest area and facilitate integrated ecosystems based forest resource
management planning and implementation.
3. Institutional Reforms
15. To facilitate integrated forest resource management at regional level, FD’s institutional
capacity should be enhanced through organizational restructuring including decentralization and
devolution  of  authority  and  redeployment  of  field  level  staff.  The  Government  agreed  to
establish four regional Conservators of Forest (CFs), devolve the authority to regional CFs, and
to divisional, range, and beat forest officers, and rationalize the head office structure in line with
the decentralization. Range and beat boundaries will be redrawn to ensure appropriate and
effective integrated forest resource management.

4. Monopoly of the State Timber Corporation (STC)
16. Distortion and inefficiency of markets results from STC’s de facto monopoly. STC enjoys
a monopoly on harvesting and sale of wood from state natural forests and plantations. Because

environment are of particular importance.
17. The Government  will  promote  private  sector  participation  in  all  forestry  operations,
including harvesting, reforestation, and silviculture of state-owned plantations through an open
competitive bidding process. To enable STC to adjust to a competitive environment, the annual
minimum area for harvesting will be allocated to STC for the next three years. At the end of
Project year three, the protection of STC will be independently reviewed.
5. Rights for Land Use
18. Beneficiaries of existing social forestry have expressed concerns about their rights to
land-use because the lease and management agreements are not extended until the trees
reach a harvestable age; and required periodical renewal of targets. New legislative framework
will  be  introduced  to  allow  appropriate  leasing/management  contract  arrangements  that
authorize FD to enter into partnerships with smallholders and private sector firms for longer term
management agreements for tree farms, woodlots, and plantations. These contracts will be
cosigned by both spouses (if both are living).
6. Public Awareness
19. Public awareness is key for promoting participation in forest resource  management
activities and for the success of policy and institutional reforms, which may attract resistance
from vested interest groups. The Project will support the development of media capacity and
media campaigns for public awareness about the benefits of deregulation and other policy
reforms by assisting the establishment of a media center within the Ministry of Forestry and
Environment.

A. Introduction
1. This report presents the summary initial environmental examination of activities proposed
under the Forest Resource Management Project (the Project). The report is based on information
gathered during the feasibility study, review of reports available in the core subproject areas
(SPAs), and data collected by the project preparation technical assistance team. The three core
SPAs, corresponding to the existing forest divisions, were selected to represent the various
climatic  and  ecological  conditions.  This  report  follows  the  initial  environment  examination
procedures developed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and listed in ADB’s Environmental
Guidelines for Selected Agriculture and Natural Resources Development Projects, 1991 and
Environmental Assessment Requirements and Environmental Review, 1993.
B. Description of the Project
2. Selected core SPAs are in the north central dry zone, the southwest and center of the
lowland wet zone, and the up-country wet and intermediate zones. The objectives of the proposed
Project  are  to  (i)  assist  the  Ministry  of  Forestry  and  Environment    (MFE)  and  the  Forest
Department  (FD)  in  their  efforts  at  sustainable  development,  effective  protection,  and
decentralized management of forest resources by facilitating establishment of a permanent forest
and  instituting  appropriate  ecosystems-based  integrated  resource  management,  including
participatory  rehabilitation and  management of  degraded  natural  forests  and  plantations;  (ii)
provide support to people-oriented forestry and private sector participation in forest resource
development and management; and (iii) strengthen the capacity of MFE and FD as well as the
community-based organizations, and enhance their institutional effectiveness.
3. To achieve the objectives, the Project will support the implementation of the Five-Year
Implementation Plan in 17 of the 19 forest divisions.1 Activities to be supported include the
Forestry Sector Master Plan and National Forest Policy that are directly linked to the project
objectives of integrated ecosystem-based forest resource management.
4. The Project follows a sector approach. The selected SPAs conform to the existing forest
divisions, with some of the divisions being combined because of their similar agro-ecological
features. Other criteria for constituting the SPAs include (i) size, (ii) security, (iii) resource base,
(iv) willingness of the communities to participate, (v) population pressure, and (vi) environmental
priority.  Three  core  SPAs  (Anuradhapura  Division,  Badulla  and  Nuwara  Eliya  divisions
[combined], and  Ratnapura  Division),  were  selected for  a  detailed  assessment  during  the
feasibility study as they appropriately represent the nature and distribution of forests in the
country and the entire range of proposed interventions. The additional seven SPAs include the
remaining secure 13 forest divisions and exclude divisions that are otherwise inaccessible or do
not conform to the agreed selection criteria.

1. Physical Resources
a. Topography
8. Most of the forests in the Ratnapura core SPA have a parallel ridge and valley topography
with an east-west trend. The general elevation of the division ranges from 30 to 2,135 meters (m)
above mean sea level. In Badulla-Nuwara Eliya SPA, elevation varies from about 900 to 2,400 m
and the SPA has a variety of complex of landform features such as mountain ranges, plateaus,
plains, valleys, and slopes. Topographically, Anuradhapura  core SPA belongs to the  lowest
peneplain with gently undulating lands. The average elevation of the area is 178 m.
b. Geology and Soil
9. Ratnapura SPA has a highland series of Precambrian rocks that are widely distributed in
the northern part of the division. The southern part has two important rock types: a southwestern
group of meta sediments and a highland group of khondalites and charnokites. The predominant
soil type in Ratnapura division is "red-yellow podsols (ultisols). This soil type is found in steeply
dissected, hilly, and rolling terrain and is developed on a wide variety of parent materials. In
mountainous areas, red-yellow podsolic soils and mountain regosols are found.
10. Badulla-Nuwara Eliya SPA belongs to the highland series of the Precambrian complex.
The major rock types are quartzites, marble, and granites. The dominant types of soil include red-
yellow podsols, reddish-brown latosols, and immature brown loams and regosols. The red-yellow
podsolic soils are widely distributed throughout Nuwara Eliya. Anuradhapura division belongs to
the highland series of Sri Lanka, and its underlying rocks are charnokite, quartzite, and marble.
The soil in the dry zone is classified as an alfisol, which broadly corresponds to the reddish-brown
earths. Chemically, this soil type is considered moderately rich soil but poor in phosphorus and
nitrogen.

a. Forest Cover
12. The latest forest inventory (1992) showed dense natural forest cover in 24 percent of Sri
Lanka’s land area, and 7 percent of the land covered with sparse, open forests. The FD and
Department of Wildlife Conservation control the natural forests.
13. Nearly 14 percent of Sri Lanka’s land area is protected area. All categories of reserves
managed by the Department of Wildlife Conservation are regarded as protected areas. The man

b. Forest Formations
15. Vegetation in Ratnapura SPA can be classified as lowland rain forest, submontane and
upper montane rain forest, wet patana grassland, and tree savanna. The dominant vegetation

16. The  vegetation  of  the  submontane  area  in  Ratnapura  is  described  as  the  Toona-

upper altitudes, in particular the family Lauraceae.
17. Natural vegetation in Badulla-Nuwara Eliya SPA includes submontane rain forest, upper
montane rain forest, tree savanna, and dry patana grassland. The vegetation of the submontane

this series are shorter than the lowland evergreen forests; lack large buttressing roots; and have a
large number of species descending from upper altitudes, in particular the family Lauraceae. The
upper montane rain forests in the core SPA replace the lower montane rain forests above 1,500
m. The upper montane rain forests are rich in epiphytes, orchids, mosses, and filmy ferns. The
trees are stunted, with umbrella-shaped crowns and twisted branches. The forest is single-storied.

A.  Economic Analysis
1. The economic analysis for the Project focuses on the three core subprojects, which are
assumed to represent the range of physical conditions that prevail in the project areas and affect
development and/or rehabilitation of natural forests and plantations. Specific field interventions
were identified for implementation at each core subproject area (SPA) and were deemed replicable
in the agro-ecological zones of the sector project. The results of the economic analyses of the core
subprojects are deemed sufficient  to  reflect  the  likely  range  of  returns for  the  whole project
including the SPAs. The economic analysis makes the following assumptions with respect to
foreign exchange rate, opportunity cost of labor, subproject costs, subproject benefits, and period
of analysis.
(i) Economic Prices: Economic border prices (world price) are used in the economic
analysis. Costs and benefits were broken into traded, nontraded, labor, and tax
factors and converted to world prices. For nontradables, a standard version factor of
0.9 was applied to derive economic prices, which is consistent with recent standard
conversion factors (SCFs) applied in Asian Development Bank and World Bank
projects. Economic prices were estimated by identifying the tradable (e.g., logs and
tea) and nontradable output.  The  economic  price  of  timber  (Table A11.1)  was
derived from the cost, insurance, and freight (CIF) price in local currency adjusted
for transport and handling costs; domestic prices were adjusted to border prices
using the SCF. The prices for internationally traded commodities are based on
World Bank commodity price projections and adjusted for quality differences. The
economic prices for nontradables were derived from their financial prices that are
assumed to remain unchanged in real terms (constant 2000 prices).
(ii) Labor: The Government minimum wage rate is SLRs135 per day; however, casual
workers demand a daily wage of between SLRs185 per day (with food and transport
provided)  and  SLRs200  per  day  (excluding  food  and  transport)  during  peak
seasons. A shadow wage rate factor of 0.811 is applied to unskilled labor in line with
seasonal unemployment and underemployment in the SPAs.
(iii) Subproject  Costs:  The  economic  costs  of  each  subproject  were  derived  by
adjusting  the  financial  cost  of  forest  field  development  including
reforestation/afforestation (excluding price escalations, taxes, and duties) by the
opportunity cost of labor and the SCF. Added to these are the subproject’s share of
project costs, relating to intermediate goods in component one (planning, boundary
demarcations, and awareness and extension) and sector capacity strengthening in
component three (civil works, vehicles, equipment, training, consulting services).
(iv) Subproject Benefits: For all but one core subproject intervention only  directly
quantifiable  benefits  have  been  included  in  the  economic  analysis.  The  direct
benefits are the value of incremental wood production and agricultural production
(annual crops, fruit crops, and tea) generated under this project in the subprojects.
Timber production has been calculated from the trees’ mean annual increment
(measured in cubic meters per hectare) and rotation age under specific silviculture
regimes and agro-ecological conditions. Any stock standing stock at the end of the

2. Woodlot Model
5. The  woodlot  model  is based  on the current community woodlot model  that  assumes 1
ha/individual in the community. Current land use is based on past tree planting programs where

up and many of the stands are currently of poor form and mixed species some of which have little

them.  The ownership will be clarified and reinforced through the issuance of long-term leases,
along with input to maximize the value of the existing stand through pole harvesting and thinning.
